docs.snippet: House Republicans demanded a travel ban from Ebola-ravaged West Africa Thursday, calling it the only sure way to protect Americans from the virus's deadly reach. Administration officials resisted, as anxiety over the disease raced through the coun...
docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans demanded a travel ban from Ebola-ravaged West Africa Thursday, calling it the only sure way to protect Americans from the virus's deadly reach. Administration officials resisted, as anxiety over the disease raced through the country and rattled the White House and Capitol Hill.

headline.main: Republicans Press for Ebola Travel Ban
headline.print_headline: Republicans Press for Ebola Travel Ban

docs.snippet: SMOKING  Clearer Skies Ahead    Not all cultures share Americans' anti-smoking sentiment, but it seems to be spreading. Royal Air Maroc, the national carrier of Morocco, has imposed a smoking ban on trans-Atlantic flights. And a much longer wait b...
docs.lead_paragraph: SMOKING Clearer Skies Ahead Not all cultures share Americans' anti-smoking sentiment, but it seems to be spreading. Royal Air Maroc, the national carrier of Morocco, has imposed a smoking ban on trans-Atlantic flights. And a much longer wait between cigarettes awaits some Japan Airlines passengers. The Japanese carrier says it will ban smoking on all international flights beginning April 1.
docs.abstract: Morocco's Royal Air Maroc imposes smoking ban on trans-Atlantic flights; Japan Airlines plans to ban smoking on all international flights beginning Apr 1 (S)

docs.snippet: As his classmates filed into lecture halls last month to start the fall semester at Bir Zeit University in the West Bank, Jamal Safi found himself stranded at home in a bleak refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.    Mr. Safi, 26, a mechanical engineerin...
docs.lead_paragraph: As his classmates filed into lecture halls last month to start the fall semester at Bir Zeit University in the West Bank, Jamal Safi found himself stranded at home in a bleak refugee camp in the Gaza Strip. Mr. Safi, 26, a mechanical engineering student from the Bureij camp, south of Gaza City, was refused entry to the West Bank by the Israeli authorities when he tried to cross from Jordan after a summer course in Egypt. So instead of starting his fifth and final year at Bir Zeit, he was chafing at his enforced idleness, one of hundreds of students from the Gaza Strip who have been denied permits to study in the West Bank.
docs.abstract: Hundreds of college students from Gaza Strip have been denied permits to study in West Bank; Israel justifies restriction, now in its third year, on security grounds, saying students from Gaza Strip include political militants who might be prone to anti-Israeli violence; ban has disrupted education of thousands of students and contributed to growing isolation of Palestinians in Gaza Strip from those in West Bank (M)

headline.main: Travel Ban Burdens Students From Gaza

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The United States today lifted its ban on travel by Americans to Communist China and disclosed that it was working through private diplomatic channels to bring Peking's Ambassador back to the Warsaw talks interrupted more t...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The United States today lifted its ban on travel by Americans to Communist China and disclosed that it was working through private diplomatic channels to bring Peking's Ambassador back to the Warsaw talks interrupted more than a year ago.
docs.abstract: US lifts ban on travel by Amers to Communist China and discloses that it is working through private diplomatic channels to bring Peking's Amb back to Warsaw talks interrupted over yr ago; both steps are part of Nixon Adm's continuing policy of seeking improved relations, but State Dept concedes no rapid response is expected

headline.main: U.S. Lifts Ban on China Travel

headline.main: UBS Instates Travel Ban for Wealth Management

docs.snippet: Al Jamahiriya, a government newspaper, has published a rare criticism of the authorities, denouncing officials who bar Libyan women from traveling abroad alone. “Turning back women traveling alone is a stark and crude abuse of basic women’s ri...
docs.lead_paragraph: Al Jamahiriya, a government newspaper, has published a rare criticism of the authorities, denouncing officials who bar Libyan women from traveling abroad alone. “Turning back women traveling alone is a stark and crude abuse of basic women’s rights,” the newspaper said. It urged Libyans to “file suits against those who interfere in our lives.” Airports and border posts are controlled by the Interior Ministry. Some conservative Islamic scholars in Libya argue that traveling Muslim women must be accompanied by a male relative.

headline.main: Libya: Paper Assails Ban on Women’s Travel
headline.print_headline: Libya: Paper Assails Ban on Women’s Travel

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The rationale for President Reagan's recent invalidation of American passports for travel to Libya is open to serious question.  Having conducted paleoanthropological research for periods of up to three months over the last six y...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The rationale for President Reagan's recent invalidation of American passports for travel to Libya is open to serious question. Having conducted paleoanthropological research for periods of up to three months over the last six years and having returned from 10 days in Libya the day your news story appeared (Dec. 11), I can sustain the arguments of others in Libya that the possibility of personal danger for Americans in that country is remote. Mr. Reagan's recent actions and his closing of the Libyan Embassy in Washington belie the fact that close scientific and academic connections exist between the U.S. and Libya. The largest single group of Libyan students is in the U.S., a number of Americans hold or have held positions in Libyan universities and there are a number of Libyan-American research projects.

headline.main: NEEDLESS U.S. BAN ON TRAVEL TO LIBYA

docs.snippet: Occupied West Bank - Bashir Barghouti, editor of the Communist weekly Al Talia, Arabic for for The Vanguard, smiled ruefully at a banner fluttering over  this town's main street: ''El Bireh, City on the Move.''         ''It may be on the move, but...
docs.lead_paragraph: Occupied West Bank - Bashir Barghouti, editor of the Communist weekly Al Talia, Arabic for for The Vanguard, smiled ruefully at a banner fluttering over this town's main street: ''El Bireh, City on the Move.'' ''It may be on the move, but we're not going anywhere,'' said Mr. Barghouti, nodding toward his colleagues Maamoun al-Sayyid and Akram Hannieh, senior editors at, respectively, the Arabic dailies Al Fajr, or The Dawn, and Ash Shaab, The People.

headline.main: 3 WEST BANK EDITORS FIGHTING TRAVEL BAN
